title: Other evolutionary and expression indices
text: far, vignettes focused workflows discussions centred around transcriptome age index (TAI). However, can also assign information gene (analogous gene age TAI). Examples include TDI, TSI, TPI (though names indices can differ studies thus standardised). sections , describe workflow transcriptome divergence index (TDI) transcriptome specificity index (TSI). index-based methods use framework TAI, aside method give factor numeric value gene (e.g.¬†gene age TAI). good news myTAIv2 rather flexible; BulkPhyloExpressionSet ScPhyloExpressionSet objects can accommodate indices, along myTAIv2 functions. Users can simply follow workflow outlined statistical tests, transformations along plotting functionalities, using non-TAI data.

title: Other evolutionary and expression indices
text: TDI (Quint et al., 2012) uses deciled dNdS values gene summarises information across genes given stage (analogous TAI) quantify overall transcriptome ‚Äòdivergence‚Äô. vast majority genes, dNdS values 1 (.e.¬†purifying selection). Therefore, TDI called transcriptome divergence index, TDI can thought capture degree purifying selection (Lotharukpong et al.¬†2024). R packages orthologr can facilitate dNdS estimation divergence-stratigraphy computation used TDI approach. Assuming divergence strata, similar TAI, TDI calculated : TDIs=‚àë=1ndsi‚ãÖeis‚àë=1neis {TDI}_s = \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} {ds}_i \cdot e_{}}{\sum_{=1}^{n} e_{}} eise_{} expression level gene ii given sample ss (e.g.¬†biological replicate developmental stage), dsi{ds}_i evolutionary age gene ii. Like TAI, developmental time-course data, TDIs{TDI}_s can grouped stage (replicate data exists) compared across developmental stages obtain overall TDI profile. pairwise comparisons (see üìà), TDIs{TDI}_s can grouped one conditions compared. single cell data, (see üìä), TDIs{TDI}_s TDI given cell cell type (pseudo-bulked).

code: library(myTAI) data("example_phyex_set_old") # this is a mock divergence strata dataset # we assign a value between 1 and 10 for all genes gene_names <- example_phyex_set_old@gene_ids example_divergence_strata <-      setNames(sample(1:10, length(gene_names), replace = TRUE), gene_names) |>     as.factor() # mock expression data taken from example_phyex_set_old@expression example_expression <-      example_phyex_set_old@expression |>      as.data.frame() |>      tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "GeneID") example_phyex_set_tdi.df <-     data.frame(phylorank = example_divergence_strata) |>     tibble::rownames_to_column(var = "GeneID") |>     dplyr::select(phylorank, GeneID) |>     dplyr::left_join(example_expression, by = "GeneID") example_phyex_set_tdi <-      myTAI::as_BulkPhyloExpressionSet(         example_phyex_set_tdi.df,         name = "Example TDI data",         index_type = "TDI") myTAI::plot_signature(example_phyex_set_tdi) ## Computing: [========================================] 100% (done) myTAI::stat_flatline_test(example_phyex_set_tdi)

title: Other evolutionary and expression indices
text: TSI (Lotharukpong et al., 2024) uses expression breadth/specificity information can obtained gene summarises information across genes given stage (analogous TAI) quantify overall transcriptome ‚Äòspecificity‚Äô. Similar TAI, TSI calculated : TSIs=‚àë=1ntsi‚ãÖeis‚àë=1neis {TSI}_s = \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} {ts}_i \cdot e_{}}{\sum_{=1}^{n} e_{}} eise_{} expression level gene ii given sample ss (e.g.¬†biological replicate developmental stage), tsi{ts}_i evolutionary age gene ii. Like TAI, developmental time-course data, TSIs{TSI}_s can grouped stage (replicate data exists) compared across developmental stages obtain overall TSI profile. pairwise comparisons (see üìà), TSIs{TSI}_s can grouped one conditions compared. single cell data, (see üìä), TSIs{TSI}_s TSI given cell cell type (pseudo-bulked). Thus, TSI represents expression-weighted mean gene expression specificity. can re-use workflow TDI shown . differences (1) need give gene expression specificity score divergence strata, (2) using real data mock dataset! TSI, accurate inference expression specificity key. According Kryuchkova-Mostacci & Robinson-Rechavi, 2017: Tau appears consistently robust method analyses. Thus, recommend tau () score introduced Yanai et al.¬†2005 measure expression specificity, though measures exist (e.g.¬†based information entropy). can also decile tau values (similar deciled dNdS divergence-strata) enable analogous comparisons TAI. Regardless measures chosen expression specificity/breadth, estimates improve data quality (.e.¬†number RNA-seq samples) quantity (.e.¬†diversity sampling multiple tissues stages, low technical noise).

title: Gene age inference
text: Genomic phylostratigraphy method date evolutionary emergence given gene (.e.¬†gene age inference), typically done genes genome. practice, one performs homology searches taxonomically-informed database NCBI NR, parse output obtain evolutionary-informed readout.  Overview gene age inference. , searching two genes genome interest taxonomically-informed database. first gene assigned relative age 1 since homologues can found far node 1. second gene assigned relative age 3 since homologues can found node 3. Adapted Barrera-Redondo et al., 2023. output can fed myTAIv2 , combined expression data, used compute transcriptome age index (TAI). specifically, gene age inference generates table storing gene age first column corresponding gene id organism interest second column. table named phylostratigraphic map (phylomap). quick users, several recent software developed gene age inference GenEra oggmap. Assuming user installed GenEra. Download taxonomically-resolved protein sequence database NCBI nr, well prot.accession2taxid taxonomy dump NCBI. Run diamond makedb. Run GenEra. hope stay debate/discussion!
code: diamond makedb \  --in nr \  --db nr \  --taxonmap prot.accession2taxid \  --taxonnodes taxdump/nodes.dmp \  --taxonnames taxdump/names.dmp genEra -q [query_sequences.fasta] -t [query_taxid] -b [path/to/nr] -d [path/to/taxdump]

title: Gene age inference
text: Despite simplicity, since first studies (Domazet-Loso et al., 2007), method concept underlying genomic phylostratigraphy subject intense discussions (Capra et al., 2013; Altenhoff et al., 2016; Liebeskind et al., 2016; Domazet-Loso et al., 2017; Yin et al., 2018; Casola 2018; Weisman et al., 2020; Futo et al., 2021; Weisman et al., 2022; Barrera-Redondo et al., 2023; etc.). crux discussion focuses homology search bias, though several studies also noted database bias (e.g., species representation contamination) evolutionary assumptions (e.g., Dollo parsimony).

title: Statistical testing with myTAI
text: myTAIv2, introduced suite permutation-based statistical testing framework test significance TAI (well TDI, TSI analogous) profiles. section, go : (1) myTAI::stat_flatline_test() evaluates whether observed TAI profile significantly different flatline (.e.¬†evolutionary trend). (2) myTAI::stat_reductive_hourglass_test() evaluates whether observed TAI profile significantly different hourglass pattern (.e.¬†consistent molecular hourglass hypothesis), well reverse myTAI::stat_reverse_hourglass_test() tests potential evolutionary patterns myTAI::stat_early_conservation_test() myTAI::stat_late_conservation_test(). (3) myTAI::stat_pairwise_test() evaluates whether TAI profiles two groups samples significantly different . Unlike stat_flatline_test(), tests (stat_reductive_hourglass_test(), stat_reverse_hourglass_test(), stat_early_conservation_test(), stat_late_conservation_test(), stat_pairwise_test()) require priori grouping developmental stage experimental conditions.

text: reductive hourglass test evaluates whether observed TAI profile significantly deviates null towards hourglass pattern, .e.¬†TAI values lower mid-stage compared early late stages. can achieved function myTAI::stat_reductive_hourglass_test().  example, can see TAI pattern consistent molecular hourglass model, observed TAI profile significantly different null distribution. can also check Cullen Frey plot (though put details tag clutter output) see null sample normally-distributed, assumption myTAI::stat_reductive_hourglass_test().  Indeed !
code: modules <- list(early = 1:3, mid = 4:5, late = 6:7) myTAI::stat_reductive_hourglass_test(   example_phyex_set_old, plot_result = TRUE,   modules = modules) ##  ## Statistical Test Result ## ======================= ## Method: Reductive Hourglass Test  ## Test statistic: 0.1111285  ## P-value: 0.008791967  ## Alternative hypothesis: greater  ## Data: Embryogenesis 2011 res_flt <- myTAI::stat_reductive_hourglass_test(   example_phyex_set_old, plot_result = FALSE,   modules = modules) myTAI::plot_cullen_frey(res_flt) ## summary statistics ## ------ ## min:  -0.1702348   max:  0.1282585  ## median:  -0.04169454  ## mean:  -0.03451902  ## estimated sd:  0.06196705  ## estimated skewness:  0.02654995  ## estimated kurtosis:  3.140974

title: Statistical testing with myTAI
text: Finally, can also test whether TAI profiles two groups samples significantly different . can achieved function myTAI::stat_pairwise_test(). example, let‚Äôs say experiment disrupt organisms‚Äô development given stage using certain perturbation (e.g.¬†drug treatment). can compare TAI profiles control treatment groups see perturbation effect TAI profile. interesting perturbed pathway thought recruit orphan genes, .e.¬†genes conserved across species. example can found . myTAIv2, can facilitate test. Since data, use example data set example_phyex_set_old create two groups samples: control treatment. can compare TAI profiles two groups using myTAI::stat_pairwise_test() function.  mock example, can see TAI profile control group (contrast1) significantly higher treatment group (contrast2), indicating perturbation effect TAI profile. p-value significant, observed TAI profile significantly different null distribution.
code: modules <- list(contrast1 = 1:4, contrast2 = 5:7) myTAI::stat_pairwise_test(   example_phyex_set_old, plot_result = TRUE,   modules = modules,   alternative = "greater") ##  ## Statistical Test Result ## ======================= ## Method: Pairwise Test  ## Test statistic: -0.0942979  ## P-value: 0.9609805  ## Alternative hypothesis: greater  ## Data: Embryogenesis 2011

title: Transforming dataset for myTAI
text: myTAI package provides function myTAI::tf() allows apply transformation function expression data PhyloExpressionSet object. function flexible can used transformation function takes matrix input. extreme example changes overall TAI pattern due RNA-seq transformations.   Indeed, myTAIv2 fitted single plotting function (myTAI::plot_signature_transformed()) evaluate robustness patterns multiple transformations, .e.  See different transformations ! general, though, earlier stages younger compared mid-stage. Across transformations, late-stage younger compared mid-stage. consistent molecular hourglass model. addition, p-values various tests (default = flat line test) can assessed myTAI::tf_stability() function. test can changed conservation_test argument, e.g.¬†conservation_test = stat_flatline_test, conservation_test = stat_flatline_test . , can see p-values flat line test 0.05 transformations. reassuring stability TAI profile across transformations. Indeed, within myTAI::plot_signature_transformed() function, can also set conservation_test parameter (e.g.¬†conservation_test = stat_flatline_test) alongside display p-values (show_p_val = TRUE), get --one plot! curious exact nature transformations used myTAI::plot_signature_transformed() myTAI::tf_stability() can check list functions applied via print(myTAI::COUNT_TRANSFORMS). Note DESeq2-based transforms (‚Äòvst‚Äô, ‚Äòrlog‚Äô) available DESeq2 installed. remove transformations, e.g.¬†‚Äúrlog‚Äù, ‚Äúrank‚Äù, ‚Äúvst‚Äù list, e.g. add transformations, e.g. apply tf_stability plot_signature functions, e.g. ScPhyloExpressionSet, important remove certain transformations ‚Äúrlog‚Äù, ‚Äúrank‚Äù, ‚Äúvst‚Äù ‚Äúlog2‚Äù suitable single cell data.
code: library(myTAI) data("example_phyex_set") # no transformation myTAI::plot_signature(example_phyex_set) ## Computing: [========================================] 100% (done) # rank transformation myTAI::plot_signature(example_phyex_set |> myTAI::tf(FUN = function(x) apply(x, 2, base::rank))) ## Computing: [========================================] 100% (done) myTAI::plot_signature_transformed(example_phyex_set) ## Computing: [========================================] 100% (done)                          ## Computing: [========================================] 100% (done)                          ## Computing: [========================================] 100% (done)                          ## Computing: [========================================] 100% (done) tf_stability_res <- myTAI::tf_stability(example_phyex_set) tf_stability_res ##         none         sqrt         log2         rank          vst         rlog  ## 5.225205e-01 4.467333e-03 2.042186e-13 2.661653e-17 2.170954e-07 7.846328e-18 COUNT_TRANSFORMS_REMOVED <- COUNT_TRANSFORMS[!names(COUNT_TRANSFORMS) %in% c("rlog", "rank", "vst")] COUNT_TRANSFORMS_ADDED <- c(COUNT_TRANSFORMS, list(new_transform = function(x) x + 1)) myTAI::tf_stability(example_phyex_set, transformations = COUNT_TRANSFORMS_REMOVED) myTAI::plot_signature_transformed(example_phyex_set, transformations = COUNT_TRANSFORMS_REMOVED)

title: Transforming dataset for myTAI
text: Alternatively (conjunction) transformations, myTAIv2 allows us check stable TAI profile progressively removing top expressed genes. can done using myTAI::plot_signature_gene_quantiles() function. default, quantiles set 1, 0.99, 0.95, 0.9 0.8 (.e.¬†removing genes quantile = 1 removing top 20% expressed genes quantile = 0.8).  , can see ‚Äòbulge‚Äô Bent Cotyledon stage driven highly expressed genes. Otherwise, TAI profile stable. also filter genes based categories using:myTAI::genes_top_variance() ‚Üí get high variance genes. myTAI::genes_top_mean() myTAI::genes_top_expr() ‚Üí get highly expressed genes, like myTAI::plot_signature_gene_quantiles()myTAI::genes_lowly_expressed() ‚Üí get lowly expressed genes gene set, can use myTAI::remove_genes() filter genes given set:  also use myTAI::select_genes() keep genes given set:  certain genes interest, can also select remove individual genes myTAI::select_genes() myTAI::remove_genes(), respectively.  sophisticated workflow extract genes drive TAI profile, check vignette ‚Üí Break TAI patterns using gaTAI
code: myTAI::plot_signature_gene_quantiles(example_phyex_set) # get top 1% variance genes (default parameters) genes.top_var <- myTAI::genes_top_variance(example_phyex_set) # get top 1% expressed genes (default parameters) genes.top_mean <- myTAI::genes_top_mean(example_phyex_set) # get lowly expressed genes with mean < 1 (default parameters) genes.low_expr <- myTAI::genes_lowly_expressed(example_phyex_set) # removing top 1% variance genes example_phyex_set.rm_top_var <-   myTAI::remove_genes(example_phyex_set, genes.top_var) # plot myTAI::plot_signature(example_phyex_set.rm_top_var) # select top 1% expressed genes example_phyex_set.select_top_expr <-    myTAI::select_genes(example_phyex_set, genes.top_mean) # plot myTAI::plot_signature(example_phyex_set.select_top_expr) ## Computing: [========================================] 100% (done) # remove two genes (AT1G02780 & AT1G03880) example_phyex_set.select_goi <-    myTAI::remove_genes(example_phyex_set, c("AT1G02780", "AT1G03880")) # plot myTAI::plot_signature(example_phyex_set.select_goi)

title: Obtaining taxonomy information
text: taxonomy() function retrieve taxonomic information. following example obtain taxonomic hierarchy Arabidopsis thaliana NCBI Taxonomy. organism argument takes scientific name query organism, db argument specifies database corresponding taxonomic information shall retrieved, e.g.¬†ncbi (NCBI Taxonomy) itis (Integrated Taxonomic Information System) output argument specifies type taxonomic information shall returned query organism, e.g.¬†classification, taxid, children. output classification data.frame storing taxonomic hierarchy Arabidopsis thaliana starting cellular organisms Arabidopsis thaliana. first column stores taxonomic name, second column taxonomic rank, third column NCBI Taxonomy id corresponding taxa. Analogous classification information can obtained different databases. output argument allows directly access taxonomy ids query organism species. far, following data bases can accesses retrieve taxonomic information: db = "itis" : Integrated Taxonomic Information Service db = "ncbi" : National Center Biotechnology Information taxonomic classifications taxonomy(..., db = "ncbi") taxonomic classifications GenEra output (since uses NCBI taxdump input). noted recent updates NCBI taxonomy meant highest order ranks (cellular root, domain, kingdom etc.) may differ.

title: Bulk PhyloExpressionSet Class ‚Äî BulkPhyloExpressionSet
text: BulkPhyloExpressionSet class designed bulk RNA-seq data biological replicates. extends base PhyloExpressionSetBase class bulk-specific functionality. Replicate Handling: Expression data across biological replicates collapsed taking row means within experimental condition developmental stage. Computed Properties: addition inherited computed properties base class, class provides: expression_collapsed - Matrix expression data collapsed across replicates (genes x identities) bootstrapped_txis - Matrix bootstrapped TXI values statistical inference (500 bootstrap samples x identities) Inherited computed properties PhyloExpressionSetBase include: gene_ids - Character vector gene identifiers identities - Character vector identity labels sample_names - Character vector sample names num_identities - Integer count unique identities num_samples - Integer count total samples num_genes - Integer count genes num_strata - Integer count phylostrata index_full_name - Full name transcriptomic index type group_map - List mapping identity names sample names TXI - Numeric vector TXI values identity TXI_sample - Numeric vector TXI values sample null_conservation_txis - Matrix null conservation TXI values statistical testing Statistical Analysis: class supports confidence interval estimation standard deviation calculation bootstrapped TXI values, enabling robust statistical analysis developmental experimental patterns.

title: PhyloExpressionSet Base Class ‚Äî PhyloExpressionSetBase
text: PhyloExpressionSetBase class serves foundation phylotranscriptomic analysis, providing shared functionality bulk single-cell data types. Abstract Properties: Subclasses must implement expression_collapsed property define expression data collapsed across replicates cells. Computed Properties: Several properties computed automatically accessed: gene_ids - Character vector gene identifiers (rownames expression matrix) identities - Character vector identity labels (colnames collapsed expression) sample_names - Character vector sample names (colnames expression matrix) num_identities - Integer count unique identities num_samples - Integer count total samples num_genes - Integer count genes num_strata - Integer count phylostrata index_full_name - Full name transcriptomic index type group_map - List mapping identity names sample names TXI - Numeric vector TXI values identity (computed collapsed expression) TXI_sample - Numeric vector TXI values sample (computed raw expression) null_conservation_txis - Matrix null conservation TXI values statistical testing Validation: class ensures consistency expression data, phylostratum assignments, groupings. gene-level vectors must matching lengths, sample groupings must consistent.

text: strata Factor vector phylostratum assignments gene strata_values Numeric vector phylostratum values used TXI calculations expression Sparse dense matrix expression counts genes rows cells columns groups Factor vector indicating identity cell belongs (derived selected_idents column metadata) name Character string naming dataset (default: "Phylo Expression Set") species Character string specifying species (default: NULL) index_type Character string specifying transcriptomic index type (default: "TXI") identities_label Character string labeling identities (default: "Cell Type") gene_ids Character vector gene identifiers (default: character(0), auto-generated expression rownames provided) null_conservation_sample_size Numeric value null conservation sample size (default: 5000) .null_conservation_txis Precomputed null conservation TXI values (default: NULL) .pseudobulk_cache Internal cache pseudobulked expression matrices different groupings .TXI_sample Internal storage computed TXI values metadata Data frame cell metadata, rownames correspond cell IDs columns contain cell attributes selected_idents Character string specifying metadata column currently used grouping cells idents_colours List named character vectors specifying colors identity level, organized metadata column name reductions List dimensional reduction matrices (PCA, UMAP, etc.) cells rows dimensions columns

title: Single-Cell PhyloExpressionSet Class ‚Äî ScPhyloExpressionSet
text: ScPhyloExpressionSet class provides comprehensive framework single-cell phylotranscriptomic analysis. Key features include: Identity Management: selected_idents property determines metadata column used grouping cells. changed, automatically updates groups property invalidates cached pseudobulk data ensure consistency. Dimensional Reductions: reductions property stores pre-computed dimensional reductions (PCA, UMAP, etc.). provided construction Seurat objects, basic PCA UMAP computed automatically. Color Management: idents_colours allows custom color schemes different metadata columns, ensuring consistent visualization across plots. Computed Properties: Several properties computed automatically accessed: available_idents - Character vector factor columns metadata can used grouping (automatically detected metadata) expression_collapsed - Matrix pseudobulked expression data (genes x identities), created summing expression within identity group TXI_sample - Named numeric vector TXI (Transcriptomic Age Index) values cell, computed using efficient C++ implementation Inherited computed properties PhyloExpressionSetBase include: gene_ids - Character vector gene identifiers identities - Character vector identity labels sample_names - Character vector sample names (cell IDs) num_identities - Integer count unique cell types/identities num_samples - Integer count total cells num_genes - Integer count genes num_strata - Integer count phylostrata index_full_name - Full name transcriptomic index type group_map - List mapping identity names cell IDs TXI - Numeric vector TXI values identity (computed pseudobulked expression) null_conservation_txis - Matrix null conservation TXI values statistical testing properties use lazy evaluation caching optimal performance.

code: # Create from Seurat object data(example_phyex_set_sc) sc_set <- example_phyex_set_sc  # Switch to different cell grouping sc_set@selected_idents <- "day" #> Loading required package: Matrix  # Access pseudobulked data (computed au  tomatically) pseudobulk <- sc_set@expression_collapsed  # Access TXI values for each cell txi_values <- sc_set@TXI_sample

title: myTAI 2.3.0.9006
text: update focused improving single-cell phyloset functionality. single-cell phylo expression object longer depends Seurat. can construct ScPhyloExpressionSet either count matrix (sparse dense), using ScPhyloExpressionSet_from_matrix, Seurat object, using ScPhyloExpressionSet_from_seurat. consistency, one can use BulkPhyloExpressionSet_from_df instead as_BulkPhyloExpressionSet. One key functionality single-cell object ability switch different identities plotting (equivalent Seurat::Idents functionality). done setting ::identities_label property object. ::available_idents property can used see options user setting current identity. setting ::idents_colours[[]], user can choose colour pallette different identities plotting, saved across different plotting calls. computation TAI values single cell now cached. Moreover, readded C++ accelerated code computation TAI, upon profiling shows faster R version handling 100000 cells (adaptive function chooses appropriate implementation object size). plotting functionality improved options added plotting (e.g.¬†plot_gene_heatmap now allows passing custom colour mapping rows (genes), instead colouring strata; plot_signature single cell readable). Bug fixes: - validation S7 objects now works properly - printing object information now works properly (instead dumping properties information)

title: myTAI 2.2.0.9006
text: importantly, new vignettes added website updated. Many thanks @LotharukpongJS Functionality wise: added input validation across functions improved plotting destroy_pattern renamed tfPS tf_PS fixed bug prevented strata transformations happening (PhyloExpressionSet now extra field @strata_values keeps track phylostratum values) added back standard deviation ribbon plot_signature finer control cell identity selection sc object fixed bugs plotting functions, plot_signature_multiple showing colours reverse, plot_genes_heatmap working given just one gene etc.

title: myTAI 2.1.0.9000
text: Single-cell support: New ScPhyloExpressionSet S7 class single-cell data, alongside BulkPhyloExpressionSet bulk data. Property renaming: conditions ‚Üí identities (conditions_label ‚Üí identities_label), counts/counts_collapsed ‚Üí expression/expression_collapsed. core logic plotting now robust bulk single-cell objects.

text: migrate myTAI 1.x 2.0: Convert data format: Update function calls: Access computed properties:
code: # Old format (data.frame) old_phyex <- PhyloExpressionSetExample  # New format (S7 object) new_phyex <- as_PhyloExpressionSet(old_phyex) # Old syntax PlotSignature(phyex_set, TestStatistic = "FlatLineTest")  # New syntax plot_signature(phyex_set, conservation_test = flatline_test) # Old syntax tai_values <- TAI(phyex_set)  # New syntax tai_values <- phyex_set@TXI # or tai_values <- TAI(phyex_set)

title: myTAI 1.0.2.9000
text: New function tfPS() : Perform transformation phylostratum values, analogous PS() transforms expression levels. Currently, tfPS() supports quantile rank transformation. New function PairwiseTest() : Statistically evaluate pairwise difference phylotranscriptomic pattern two contrasts based   computations. New function pairScore() : Compute pairwise difference TAI (TDI) score.

title: myTAI 1.0.2.9000
text: Removed taxonomy() references due deprecation taxize(). needed CRAN submission.

title: myTAI 1.0.1.9000
text: New function PlotSignatureTransformed() : Plot evolutionary signatures across transcriptomes RNA-seq transformations New function tfStability(): Perform Permutation Tests Different Transformations (test robustness p-values given test (e.g.¬†FlatLineTest(), ReductiveHourglassTest(), ReverseHourglassTest(), EarlyConservationTest() LateConservationTest()) expression data transformations) New function LateConservationTest() : Perform Reductive Late Conservation Test (test high-mid-low (high-high-low) TAI TDI pattern) New function lcScore() : Compute Hourglass Score LateConservationTest internal rcpp functions now using Eigen automatically enable parallelization

title: myTAI 1.0.1.9000
text: PlotSignature() updated able perform TestStatistic = "LateConservationTest". PlotSignature() now prints p-value subtitle rather via ggplot2::annotate(). tf() now pseudocount parameter, useful performing logarithmic transformations genes 0 counts. tf() now supports vst rlog transformations DESeq2. tf() now intergerise parameter, needed applying vst rlog transformations. tf() updated documentation performing rank transformation, assigns ranks gene expression values within stage, based relative positions compared values. Improvements existing test functions (ecScore(), rhScore() reversehourglassScore()) give message phylotranscriptomic pattern unlikely follow test statistics. FlatLineTest() - newly returns ks test statistics fitting gamma FlatLineTest() - improved fitting FlatLineTest() - cpp functions newly parallelized progress bar implemented computation permutations

title: myTAI 0.9.0
text: new function ReverseHourglassTest() perform Reverse Hourglass Test. Reverse Hourglass Test aims statistically evaluate existence reverse hourglass pattern based TAI TDI computations. corresponding p-value quantifies probability given TAI TDI pattern (phylotranscriptomics pattern) follow hourglass like shape. p-value < 0.05 indicates corresponding phylotranscriptomics pattern rather follow reverse hourglass (low-high-low) shape. new function reversehourglassScore() computing Reverse Hourglass Score Reverse Hourglass Test
